title: Should you play all 5 roles?
body:
Now that the improved queuing has been introduced where you are only required to main two roles, is there a point to playing all 5 roles besides filling?

For example, learning enemy champion kits and cooldowns, or learning other mechanic that are more important like wave control for a top laner to be used as an adc for bot lane. 

Do you think it is useful to main more than 2 roles?

replies.body: If you play all 5 roles you can learn how to play against all types of champs
Not necessarily.
It may not necessarily make you invincible, but it will allow for a fundamental understanding of counterplay, which you must admit is a very beneficial thing to have.

This ^

It was very useful for figuring out how kits like Leblanc and Ekko worked.  Without playing them or a lot of experience, it seemed like they could warp around the map all willy-nilly.
If Leblanc ever becomes free, I must try her out, if only for counterplay research.

I strongly recommend it.

I can't tell you how many times I've tried out a champ because they kicked my ass, only to find they were basically useless in my hands because there were lots of restrictions on the tricks I saw them pull.

I used to (typically) think Fizz was broken and played him on free week and saw how insanely high his E CD was. IMHO, most, if not all champions need at least some skill to be played effectively and most if not all can be counter played as well.

You don't have to know how to play all 5 roles, but mastering one and knowing how to play the other without costing too much for one's team is usually the best way through.

Trying to play and improve on 5 roles at a time will not really get you anywhere if you are looking to climb, as you have too many things to learn at once. Shrink the focus to one or two cuts a lot of slack and time for you to improve on one thing. Of course one *should* know how all 5 roles work to have a better understanding of power curves/team comp/etc, but knowing how to play them is completely optional.

Then unless you main support which gets you that role 99% of the time, sticking to just two is good enough.

Generally I'd say that you should focus on 2 roles, and be able to play the last three at a level at least 1 league below your present league. This is simply for understanding and helping you learn the game as a whole. IE, if you can be a Plat Mid/Jungle, you shouldn't be worse than a Gold in ADC/Support/Top.

The concept doesn't translate as well to lower leagues, if you're Silver/Bronze, then totally tunnel vision until you're at least Gold Tier, 100%. At that point you're still largely needing to learn your 'main', much less anything else.

I wouldn't recommend playing more than two roles consistently, but I'd recommend you know how they play.

Being able to predict the actions and priorities of your allies and enemies is an invaluable skill.  

This is especially useful as a jungler since you can predict when and where the enemy will ward, which match-ups will need assistance or can be left alone, which enemies will be vulnerable to ganks, etc.

In my opinion, to climb elo i dynQ, one should:

1) Understand all 5 roles
2) understand basic mechanics and abilities for as many champs as possible
3) stick to maining 1 role with a comfort 2nd role

I'd say you should have at least 1-2 champions that you can play objectively well in each role. I don't care if you exclusively play only AP assassins or Riven or Ezreal or whatever, you should be able to function in the other four roles too. I hate when people bitch that they didn't get top or mid or whatever and act like a jerk support or jungle all game, or feed their ass off as an ADC they've never played.

You should learn all roles to know how they play, it will make you better player. But after you've done trials with a lot of champs and roles and find one or two that you like, it's important to stick to them (if climbing is your goal). Being good at a lot of things but not amazing at any one will make you a 'slower' player in general, in terms of split-second mechanics. In the long term if you're regularly rotating champs you only have 20ish games on, you're at a disadvantage and may find your games have a larger 'luck' aspect than say, a one-trick's.
I feel like you should know how all 5 roles work and play them all from time to time, but pick a couple to really "main".

Learning all 5 roles is pretty important. If you know all 5 roles, then you will understand the issues each role faces and be a lot more understanding when on a team. That said, by no means do you need to master each role. 
I hardly understand how to jungle correctly and ADC feels like there is too much pressure to kill every minion and get fed. But I've played them and know what they have to deal with. So I can understand why the Jungler hasn't ganked for me or why the ADC hasn't gotten a single kill 10 minutes into the match. 
At least trying each role is good to help you know what to expect when others play the role and even help you predict the enemy better.
play all champs all roles. play champs in all roles. why not its a game, have fun enjoy it.

Learning all the roles is a great idea. It helps you understand their palystyle and their needs to get far in a game. 
You don't need to play each role 20% of the time, you just need to play a few games of each to be able to understand them at a basic level.

If you're going to "main" more than two, please do it outside of ranked. I enjoy nothing more than pulling up my lane opponent in ranked to find he's got 200 ranked games played with no more than 5 on any given champ. Even if I'm countered, it's a free win.

You don't need to learn all five roles. If you want to be somewhat viable in every role, which is possible in a way that is time consuming, and will slow down your climb for quite some time. I recommend you pick one meta pick champ for each role, then two pocket picks for each role that you enjoy playing as back up, in case that one meta pick champ is banned or taken away. Reguardless, as most people here said, is not highly needed that you play all five roles. The more you play the game, the more you come to understand about champions you don't play without even playing them. Yes, you won't be able to understand them in extreme details like the people who actually main those certain roles you don't main or champs for that specific role but, that bit of knowledge that you have in your pocket will allow you to be of some kind of use for your team as long as you play around that bit of knowledge that you have where the window for mistakes is smallest.
As others have already said, I think it's important to try a bit and know the basics of every role, but to focus on one main role to improve and climb.

If you actually care about improving as a player rather than just being a solo queue hero that stomps people with no coordination, then yeah, of course learning all roles to a decent level helps because at the end of the day they all tie together. Even if you have zero intention of actually playing those extra roles you learned, you can still help your team out and micromanage them when necessary.

I've found that its easiest to concentrate on just 2 roles. I generally go for Mid or ADC because I simply don't trust anyone else to be the main damage dealer in team fights.

I stay away from Top because its hard to team fight from top lane (especially after TP nerfs) and I've also found that its too Counterpick dependent. Your impact on the game seems limited (if you're team is winning you'll do well enough to win, if not, then you can't do much). You're not likely to be there when the game is decided. 

Support deals too little damage but I've had some success playing full damage Annie support. 

Not a big fan go JG; counter-JG really puts me on tilt and I have no idea how the other JG constantly has a sense of where I am. Also, I can never seem to persuade my team mates not to over push.

When you want to improve, you should focus on normalizing as many variables as possible. There are too many variables in League of Legends for you to just get better when everything is completely different every game.

Even if you want to get good at all 5 roles, then you should rotate between what you're focusing on. One week of adc, then one week of top, then one week of mid, etc. And when you do each of those roles you should only be focusing on playing a single champion in that role, maybe two if there's a decent chance of your main being banned.
Play all 5 rolls, main one, keep a strong backup.
